item.title: U.S. Coast Guard Boards Tanker Carrying Venezuelan Oil
item.description: Kristi Noem, the homeland security secretary, said a vessel had been “apprehended.” It was the second action this month against a tanker carrying Venezuelan oil.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Nehamas, Anatoly Kurmanaev and Christiaan Triebert

item.title: Best of 2025, Canada Edition
item.description: Here are the Canadian standouts from The Times’s culture, books and arts coverage over the last year.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Richard Drew/Associated Press
item.media:description: Margaret Atwood’s memoir is one of The Times’s Notable Books of 2025.

item.title: What Fans Did to Attend a Bad Bunny Show in Mexico City
item.description: The award-winning Puerto Rican artist, the most-streamed on the planet, is performing eight concerts in Mexico. People flocked from all over the world, including the United States.
item.dc:creator: James Wagner and Luis Antonio Rojas
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times

item.title: U.S. and Venezuela Jam Caribbean GPS Signals to Thwart Attacks, Raising Flight Hazard
item.description: Military brinkmanship between President Trump and Nicolás Maduro of Venezuela has led to an increase in electronic warfare in the region.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen and Anatoly Kurmanaev
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Alejandro Cegarra for The New York Times
item.media:description: A member of Venezuela’s security forces on the tarmac at Maiquetia International Airport in Caracas this month. The F.A.A. has issued a warning to all aircraft operating there.

item.title: How Venezuela Went From U.S. Ally to Trump Target
item.description: Closely tied to Washington during much of the Cold War, Venezuela has gone through political upheavals over the years that now make it a major enemy in the eyes of the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Henry Griffin/Associated Press
item.media:description: Venezuelans surrounding Vice President Richard M. Nixon’s motorcade in Caracas in 1958.

item.title: Rafael Ithier, Ambassador of Puerto Rican Music, Dies at 99
item.description: Leading the acclaimed salsa group El Gran Combo de Puerto Rico, he brought the music of his native island to a worldwide audience for more than 60 years.
item.dc:creator: Alex Williams
item.category: El Gran Combo de Puerto Rico

item.title: Toronto Man Accused of Working With ISIS Faces Terror Charges Targeting Jews and Women
item.description: After two failed abductions, three men were arrested, one of whom is charged with working to support the Islamic State terrorist group.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Eugen Sakhnenko for The New York Times
item.media:description: The skyline of Toronto. Terror charges were filed after investigations into two failed kidnapping attempts in the Toronto area earlier this year.

item.title: U.S. Kills 5 People Accused of Trafficking Drugs in Another Boat Strike
item.description: The attack killed 5 people, the latest known fatalities since the attacks began in September. The Trump administration has accused those on the boats of ferrying narcotics but provided little proof.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper
item.media:credit: Valerie Plesch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Pentagon officials on Thursday announced the 27th known lethal operation in President Trump’s campaign against drug cartels in South America.

item.title: Mexico’s Security Chief on His Fight Against the Cartels
item.description: Omar García Harfuch spoke to The New York Times about the country’s aggressive cartel offensive and his relationship with the White House.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Omar García Harfuch, Mexico’s security secretary, during an interview at his office this month.

item.title: Can This Man Finally Defeat Mexico’s Cartels?
item.description: Omar García Harfuch is overseeing one of the most aggressive offensives in years against Mexico’s powerful criminal groups. Many before him have failed.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas and Luis Antonio Rojas
item.media:credit: Luis Antonio Rojas for The New York Times
item.media:description: Omar García Harfuch, Mexico’s secretary of Security and Citizen Protection, in his office.

item.title: U.S. Military Announces 4 Killed in 26th Boat Strike
item.description: The attack on Wednesday brings the total number killed to at least 99 since the Trump administration began bombing boats suspected of ferrying drugs in the Caribbean Sea and the Pacific Ocean.
item.dc:creator: Adam Sella
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: U.S. attacks on boats off South America have drawn the ire of legal experts and many members of Congress, who contend that the strikes amount to extrajudicial killings and, potentially, war crimes.

item.title: Trump’s Claim That Venezuela ‘Stole’ U.S. Oil Fields Sets Off a Nationalist Reaction
item.description: President Trump said the United States wanted to reclaim expropriated oil assets, setting off a nationalist reaction in a country where the resource holds a mythical status.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Derricks in the Maracaibo oil fields of Venezuela in the early 20th century. American oil companies invested millions of dollars in the region, generating profits that flowed to the United States, rather than Venezuela.

item.title: House Rejects Measure to Bar Strikes Inside Venezuela
item.description: The Democratic measure was defeated mostly along party lines, along with another resolution that would have halted the military’s escalating campaign of boat attacks.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: U.S. military aircraft in Ceiba, Puerto Rico, on Tuesday. For months, the U.S. military has been building up a large naval force there as President Trump continues to threaten to attack Venezuela.

item.title: Canada’s Population Shrinks Amid Tightened Immigration
item.description: The government has greatly restricted the number of work and study permits issued to foreigners following an unpopular immigration boom during the pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.media:description: International students and others lining up for buses in Brampton, Canada, where many students and temporary workers from India have settled.

item.title: Trump Revised Chevron’s Venezuela Deal. Maduro’s Oil Trader Profited.
item.description: A firm controlled by a businessman tied to a seized tanker carrying Venezuelan oil has sold millions of barrels from a Chevron-operated oil field.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Tyler Pager
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: A statue outside Venezuela’s state oil company PDVSA headquarters in Caracas.

item.title: Trump Orders Blockade of Some Oil Tankers to and From Venezuela
item.description: The move is an escalation of military operations and a pressure campaign against Nicolás Maduro, Venezuela’s leader. But its scope and economic impact are not clear.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong, Simon Romero, Charlie Savage and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil tankers anchored in Punto Fijo, Venezuela, in 2021. Venezuela relies entirely on tankers to export its oil to world markets.

item.title: Team Races Against Time to Save a Tangled Sea Lion in British Columbia
item.description: Experts tracked the sea lion, which had a rope around its neck, for over a month before they were able to catch up to it in Cowichan Bay, Canada.
item.dc:creator: Rylee Kirk

item.title: Penguins Become Prey for the Pumas of Patagonia
item.description: In Argentina, the return of pumas brought top predators back to the landscape — much to penguins’ dismay.
item.dc:creator: Alexa Robles-Gil
item.category: Proceedings of the Royal Society B (Journal)

item.title: When the Bones Were Good, These Bees Buried Their Babies
item.description: A cave in the Dominican Republic concealed thousands of years worth of animal bones that had been turned into nests by prehistoric bees.
item.dc:creator: Jack Tamisiea

item.title: US Boat Strikes Shift to Pacific, Placing Colombia on Watch
item.description: All the strikes in recent weeks have taken place in the Pacific, reflecting Colombia’s role in the drug trade and the feuding between Bogotá and Washington.
item.dc:creator: Simon Romero
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
item.media:description: Video images posted by the U.S. Southern Command on Monday showed what the U.S. military said were strikes on three narcotrafficking vessels in the eastern Pacific Ocean.

item.title: Hegseth Declines to Show Lawmakers Boat Strike Video
item.description: The defense secretary joined the secretary of state on Capitol Hill to deliver the first classified briefings to include all members of the House and Senate on the maritime attacks.
item.dc:creator: Robert Jimison and Megan Mineiro
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Eric Lee for The New York Times
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Pete Hegseth briefed lawmakers on Tuesday on the military’s strikes on boats in international waters.

item.title: Mark Carney Caught in Canada’s British Spelling Debate
item.description: Some words spelled the British way are emerging in Canadian government documents. A group of language experts say the changes undermine Canada’s identity.
item.dc:creator: Vjosa Isai
item.media:credit: Justin Tang/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney of Canada speaking in Ottawa last week. As a former leader of England’s central bank Mr. Carney spent years exposed to British English.

item.title: U.S. Sends Cubans to Naval Station at Guantánamo Bay
item.description: The transfer of nearly two dozen men this week restarted a Trump administration deportation operation on the base after a two-month hiatus.
item.dc:creator: Carol Rosenberg
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: About 730 men have been held at the base by Immigration and Customs Enforcement, including this week’s arrivals.

item.title: Trinidad and Tobago Sides With U.S. in Battle Against Venezuela, Military Tool Suggests
item.description: The United States and Trinidad say U.S. Marines installed a radar in Tobago to combat drugs — but this war materiel isn’t designed for operations based at sea or on land.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Center for Strategic and International Studies
item.media:credit: Andrea De Silva/Reuters
item.media:description: A U.S. radar at the A.N.R. Robinson International Airport in Trinidad and Tobago.

item.title: Venezuela’s Oil Is a Focus of Trump’s Campaign Against Maduro
item.description: In public, the White House says it is confronting Venezuela to curb drug trafficking. Behind the scenes, gaining access to the country’s vast oil reserves is a priority.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Adriana Loureiro Fernandez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Oil drilling equipment in Cabimas, Venezuela. The country has about 17 percent of the world’s known oil reserves, nearly four times the amount in the United States.

item.title: U.S. Strikes 3 More Boats in Eastern Pacific, Killing 8
item.description: The attacks brought the number killed since the Trump administration began the strikes on suspected drug smugglers to at least 95.
item.dc:creator: Nathan Willis
item.category: US Strikes on Alleged Drug Traffickers (2025- )
United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: U.S. Southern Command
item.media:description: An image taken from video released on Monday by the U.S. Southern Command.

item.title: ‘Titaníque,’ Singing and Spoofing Celine Dion, Sets Sail for Broadway
item.description: This zany musical made it from the basement of a Manhattan grocery to London’s West End, and now hopes to become Broadway’s next hit comedy.
item.dc:creator: Michael Paulson
item.media:credit: Evelyn Freja for The New York Times
item.media:description: The “Titaníque” team includes, from top to bottom, the director Tye Blue, the writer Constantine Rousouli, the actor Marla Mindelle and the music supervisor Nicholas James Connell.

item.title: Kast’s Victory in Chile Is Another Win for Global Right-Wing Movement
item.description: José Antonio Kast, who was elected president on Sunday, is the latest conservative to rise to power promising strict law and order measures.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Claudio Santana/Getty Images
item.media:description: José Antonio Kast and his wife, Maria Pia Adriazola, celebrating on Sunday in Santiago, Chile, after the runoff election.

item.title: U.S. Military Plane and JetBlue Flight Nearly Collided Over Caribbean, Radio Traffic Shows
item.description: The Air Force refueling tanker was flying without its location transponder activated and could not be detected by air traffic control.
item.dc:creator: Riley Mellen
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Ricardo Arduengo/Reuters
item.media:description: A U.S. Air Force air-to-air refueling tanker took off from an airport in St. Croix in late November. A similar type of aircraft nearly collided with a JetBlue flight on Friday over the Caribbean, according to air traffic control radio communications.

item.title: José Antonio Kast Elected President of Chile
item.description: José Antonio Kast has promised to reverse Chile’s recent surge in violent crime. He also says he will deport undocumented migrants.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola
item.media:credit: Javier Torres/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: José Antonio Kast with supporters after voting in Paine, Chile, on Sunday.
